Hi John, 
Unfortunately ICMA does not currently have many documents on this issue. I would recommend that you check out the topic pages for Public Works ( http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/Topic/221/Public_Works ) and Planning ( http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/Topic/204/Planning ) to see if there are any other helpful documents besides the one recommended below. 
-"Providing Water and Sanitation to the Urban Poor" (icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/301654) is a white paper that you may find relevant to your utility expansion planning. 
I hope you find this document and the topic pages useful. If you have any more questions feel free to ask. 
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern 
rsaywitz@icma.org

author: John Osborne
text:
In unincorporated Manatee County, FL, we have a large utility service area. We have allowed extensions within this area as long as they built consistent with our utility master plan. However, this area is typically low density (less than 3 du/acre), which in many instances there are very few customers per linear foot for the infrastructure. 
Do you have any criteria with your community's utility extension policies that address:
- Minimum net density / customers per linear foot
- Public utility provider getting reimbursed for utility upsizing costs or developer being the at risk party for this reimbursement
- ROI analysis with specific standards
- Criteria involve timing of any utility upsizing and future roadway improvements / widening
- Other criteria
In addition, do you have a utility masterplan/model that provides guidance on:
- Identifies areas of your community that have capacity
- Ability to run different land use scenarios
- If so, which model do you use?
Thank you for your assistance.
John Osborne, Planning Official
Manatee County, FL
title: Utility Extension Criteria, Master Planning & Modeling
